Fire.-A severe fire, which threatened wide de-.
struc,ion to the village Of Saratoga Springs, and
which was arrested only by the most hazardous and
arduous exertons Of the citizens, took place the
night Of the 10Th ult. The academy, Mr.. Reeds
tavern house, store owned by Messrs. Brinkerhoff
& Co. and dwelling house owned by Mr. H ],
Belts. and occupied by Judge Cook, were entirely
destroyed. The loss of property is estimated al
between and $1,000, 82so0 Of which was insured.
There was no engine in the village,

BOLIVAR A TRAIToR!-By Capt. Center Of the brig
Lama, which arrived last evening in ITO days from Calao,
ceye the nnwelcome confirmation of suspicious hitherto
d,screted concerning the reputed second Washington.
Capt c. reports that about the 9Th of September, Bolivar
declared himself President of Peru for lite, with power
appoint his The Vice President also ap-
pointed for life and his eldest son TO succeed him. Boil
exceedingly unpopular at Lima, and the place in
very unsettled sateseveral officers had been shot for
being engaged in conspiracy against him. Admiral
t;use his trial when the Lama left The Colombian
iropps. about $500 in number from AFRICA ordered
taken the Lima troops with him to Colombia.

Extract Of a letter from Gerry intelligent .amsri
can gentleman, noW in London, to his friend In
this city. dated .Nouember last.


"The condition of England. at this time, is any
thing but cheering. The tariffs system is the heavi.
est blow she ever received from our country. She
begins TO feel i;s operation, and seeks TO quarrel
with Us about the Northern Boundary. The real
fact is. the is to be waged with our country
but with its prosperity. The United States have
hitherto afforded the best market for her manufac-
tures-itisnow diminishing, and Manchester, Leeds
and Birmingham feel the vibration of every loon,
that is erected in our country. England also, is in
danger Of losing much Of her continental market
France, Holland, Russia, Germany, &c. sc. are
paronizng manufactures to an extent that fills the
uisest heads in England with dismay. l am aware
that the oppo.ition here is always pretending evil but
even the friends Of the ministerial party confess an
alarm.


The corn laws are the ostensible prominent griev.
ance, but the manufacturing distress is the evil
which threatens most loudly and permanently the in
terests and tranquility Of England.


" Y To,n 4J,

The schooner Climax. at Norfolk om Antigua
and Port Spain, reports that the inhabitants Of the
latter were very much dissatisfied with the late
der in council relative TO the prohibition of Ameri
can vessels from entering their ports. A piraticai
TWO topsail schooner crulzng of the Windward
Islands, and had committed robberes several
vessels among which were some Americans.


Lozp life u6o1e sairs-A Montreal paper relates re-
markabe instance of stealing in high life. Two ladies OF
respectable connexions went into merchants in that
city to purchase articles. While standing at the
counter, one ut them observed by the dealer
ceal piece OF muslin under her scarf.


There were several other people in the store, and the
merchant from respect to her respectable rank and
nexons wishing expose before them ALL polite
y requested her to walk into his back shop She, suspec
ting bis object, slipped the muslin down upon the
she entered the other apartment and afterwards stouty
denied that she had the article in her hand. The attempt
theft. however, observed not only by the merchants
but by his shopman and some OF the purchasers.


The Reservoir OF the Ohio Canal, on the Licking
Summit, contracted for by Mr.. John Sheather, of
Rochester, New Yorks is completed. 1t contains
Of about 500 acres, and is intended supply
the main line the canal with in dry seasons.
The embankmeni, with wall fhewn timber n the
centre of the bank has cost the state about $500


BRISTOL, R Ion Tuesday morning last
about O'Clock, fire broke out 10 barn situated in
the south part of Bristol, owned by w. H. D'Wof,
Esq. which with its contents, and small two story
dwelling house contiguous. the property Of Mr.. Jo-
seph Waldronw ina short time entirely consumed.
In the barn at the time o,he Ere three horses,
three hogs, and several dogs, all OF which excepting
a hog and dog, were destroyed with the barn. In
attempting to rescue the animals. MIR. D'Wolf was
considerably injured.

LATEST FROM ENGLAND.
BY the packet ship Corin.hian, Capt. Davis, We

state that owing to the heat Of the season, most
the cargoes of fish from Newfoundland had arrived
in bad condition.

An investigation having been instituted into tn,
affairs Of the contraband packages, placed among
MIR. Secratary Canning's baggage on his return iron

were placed on board at Boulogne, not without tn,
concurrence of one Of the suit Of the Right Hon. Gen
tleman. Though without any address on the out
side, one of them, ON being opened, was found L
contain direction TO waiter, at the Ship Tavern
at Dover. The servant and the waiter have beer
dismissed from their respective situations.

Nothing but the presence Of strong British ar.
mament, in the Tagus, has saved Portugal from
invasion by the Spaniards-- Ferdinand being vastl,
displeased at the introduction OF the new Consttu
tion.


Mr.. Southey has declined the seat to which he
was elected in Parament--not possessing the re-
quisite real estate.


The malady in Groningcn had not abated.
A fire in Batavia had destroyed l80 houses.
Executions were still going on in Consantinople
The Grand Seignor has executed 5000 Of his sub
ects. The ladies are thrown into the sea in sacks
A 60 gun ship, built for the Pacha Of Egypt, had
been launched at Leghorn.


Six unsuccessful attacks had been made upon the
Acropolis by the Turks.


a Mausoeum Is 10 De erected al otratordupon

A cotton mill belonging TO Cussons, Bradley &

The long pending treaty between Persia and Eng.
land, has been received in London.


The pe,sians claim some successe, over the Rus
slams.


The Times renews the rumor that the exertions
Of England and France have induced the Turks to
make concessions in favor of the Greeks. There is
no good foundation for the rumor.
London, .Nov. 25.
1t is stated from Vienna and Bucharest that the
Sultan had ratified the Convention of Akerman be
fore the expiration Of the stipulated period of four
weeks.


The news from Greece is generally Of a more fa-
vorablc aspect A great number of the inhabitants
of Rumelia had rebelled against the Porte.
Major Wilcox has arrived this morning at the
East India House, over land from India. This Off
has brought the long pending treaty between this
country and Persia.

Fire.-A severe fire, which threatened wide de-.
struc,ion to the village Of Saratoga Springs, and
which was arrested only by the most hazardous and
arduous exertons Of the citizens, took place the
night Of the 10Th ult. The academy, Mr.. Reeds
tavern house, store owned by Messrs. Brinkerhoff
& Co. and dwelling house owned by Mr. H ],
Belts. and occupied by Judge Cook, were entirely
destroyed. The loss of property is estimated al
between and $1,000, 82so0 Of which was insured.
There was no engine in the village,

full articles.headline: MENTOR.
full articles.article:
Nezy YoTS, jan. 3.
BOLIVAR A TRAIToR!-By Capt. Center Of the brig
Lama, which arrived last evening in ITO days from Calao,
ceye the nnwelcome confirmation of suspicious hitherto
d,screted concerning the reputed second Washington.
Capt c. reports that about the 9Th of September, Bolivar
declared himself President of Peru for lite, with power
appoint his The Vice President also ap-
pointed for life and his eldest son TO succeed him. Boil
exceedingly unpopular at Lima, and the place in
very unsettled sateseveral officers had been shot for
being engaged in conspiracy against him. Admiral
t;use his trial when the Lama left The Colombian
iropps. about $500 in number from AFRICA ordered
taken the Lima troops with him to Colombia.

full articles.headline: DELlJY.aRE LEGISLATURE.
full articles.article:
JAN. 5-As has been observed, the Senate did
not form quorum until the afternoon OF this day
j. when all The members were present. The returns
of The elections in the several counties were read
#when it appeared that Joseph England was elected
q a Senator from New Castle County for the term OF
8three years-John HincktR, from Kent-and
z Peter Robinson, from Sussex-for the same teni.
& Henry Whiteley was elected Speaker, and having
taken the oath of Office, qualified the me nbers.
&uipnry Stout was chosen Clerk-when the Senate
&adournrd to 10 o'clock next day.


JAN 4-Mr. Robinson presented the petition OF
E. Li,tell Of Phadelph pha, praying for authority to
Ivend certain Books by Lottery: which was read
land referred to Messrs Robinson Spruance aud
No. Polk. Messrs. Robinson and England were ap
ponted on the part Of the Senate to act jointly with
"a Committee Of the House, to inform the Governor
&hat a quorum Of both Houses had convened and
were ready TO receive any communication he might
#haye to make. Messrs. Green and England were
#appointed Committee to draft and report Rules
Nor the government of the Senate during the pre-,
sent session. John NJ. Clayton, Secretary Of State,
8presen.ed written Message from he Governor,
(which was read, and 100 copies thereof ordered to
&be printed and the Senate adjourned TO 5 O'Clock,
8p. M.


8. p MA com muncaon was received from
#IVlard Hall, Esq. transmitting seven Bills drafted
pursuant TO Resolution OF the General Assembly,
adopted in 1924. The Speaker laid on the table
4 the Memorial Of Jonathan Elliott proposing to pub.


sh Debates on the adoption Of the Federal Consl,
4 tuition, and soliciting the patronage OF the Legisla-
n lure The Memorial was read and referred 10
81 Messrs. C. Polk, Engtad and Brinckt@. Messrs.
a Brinckip and W. ". Potk were appointed to
a examine and report the unfinished business Of last
session.


n JAN. 5.--Messrs. Spruance and W. ". Polh
n were appointed Committee on Elections. MIR
81 Brinckl9, from the Committee on the unfinished
Il business OF last session, reported fifteen bills a
Il number Of bills received first reading to-day
q which occupied the principal part Of the sitting
II Messrs. England, Robinson, and BrinchlG were
q appointed Committee TO have such repairs made


IN the Senate Chamber as may be deemed useiu
N and necessary.


N JAN. 6--The Senate met this morning and ad
" ourned Immediately, in order to have some repair:
"a made in their Chamber.


HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
"a JAM. a. The Speaker laid on the table Memo


rial from II. G.. Carey & I. Lea Of Philadelphia


asking the patronage Of the Legislature 10 :
a publication on Canals, Bridges, sc. Mr. Ctpm,n
n presented several Bills drafted by Willard Hall
81 Esq. in obedience to Resolution OF the Genera
# Assembly. resolution was presented by MIR


Black. and adopted, requesting the Trustee o


.he Fund for establishing Schools in this State, Il
furnish the House with statement showing 10 wha


amount subscriptions have been made on the part =
h the said fund to the stock OF the Chesapeake an,


Delaware Canal; ana what amount of stock IN th


said Company has been purchased under The provis


ions OF an act entitled Az Act authorizing sub


scrlp,ion to the stock Of the Chesapeake and Della


ware Canal, passed on the 5th Of February, 1898


also what sums have been paid, as well as The amour


yet due, If any, upon subscriptions on purchases


The Governors Message was received and read.


Jss. 5.-Thc Speaker presented Report from VIM I


Brobson Esq the Agent of this State to settle aud adus


its military claims against The United States The follow


ing petitions presented BY Mr.. Burton, from Robel


Morris and Thomas Robinson of Sussex County, for author


y to build grist and mill Bow Bridge Branch


said County by Mr.. Craiord, from Trustees of Middle


town Academy, for authority to raise money by Loer,


TO endow said Academy. Messrs. Raymond C0r6if Bate


Burton and Taylor appointed Committee on claim

De'arsare Legisldtare-We tender thanks to our
friends at Dover who have furnished with from
the Journals OF the Legislature. We have made
~ OF what appeared to be most interesting, believing that
his plan will be acceptable than the publication in
detail OF each days proceedings, which would necessarily
embrace much matter OF Importance only to those mme-
datcy concerned.

DiED-On board the U. S. Sch'r. Grampus, on her
passage from Pensacola TO Havana the morning OF the
30th November Lieut. Comd't JOSEPH CASSlN, of the
United States Navy and at O'Clock in the afternoon Of
the day, his remains committed to the deep,
with military honors.

sage without word Of comment We presume Mr..
Ilaker for agrees in opinion with almost every body
else, that the Message about poor thing Of the kind


has been given to the world during the last half century


Had a DEMOCRATIC Governor produced such Mes

Extract Of a letter from Gerry intelligent .amsri
can gentleman, noW in London, to his friend In
this city. dated .Nouember last.


"The condition of England. at this time, is any
thing but cheering. The tariffs system is the heavi.
est blow she ever received from our country. She
begins TO feel i;s operation, and seeks TO quarrel
with Us about the Northern Boundary. The real
fact is. the is to be waged with our country
but with its prosperity. The United States have
hitherto afforded the best market for her manufac-
tures-itisnow diminishing, and Manchester, Leeds
and Birmingham feel the vibration of every loon,
that is erected in our country. England also, is in
danger Of losing much Of her continental market
France, Holland, Russia, Germany, &c. sc. are
paronizng manufactures to an extent that fills the
uisest heads in England with dismay. l am aware
that the oppo.ition here is always pretending evil but
even the friends Of the ministerial party confess an
alarm.


The corn laws are the ostensible prominent griev.
ance, but the manufacturing distress is the evil
which threatens most loudly and permanently the in
terests and tranquility Of England.


" Y To,n 4J,

f-.v.x The subscriber offers for sale FARM
9fTs1 adjoining the Farm where he now dwels

n st quality. There is the premises comfortable
dwelling house, barn and other buildings and
ensive apple orchard Of lhe best fruit 1t convenient
market, being within miles Of the Town Of Newcastle
about the distance from the Village of Christians and
five and half miles from Wilmington. Any person
wishing purchase, will be shown the property by calling
on the subscriber. BENZ. MARLEY.

Washington, January 9 A Comet has been dis.
covered tor several evenings Of as week, visible a,
| small distance 5. of the planet Mars--it is al
present too distant form any judg gment OF
It's contse, but we mention the fact 60 draw the at
tention Of Astronomers to it. Intel.


The schooner Climax. at Norfolk om Antigua
and Port Spain, reports that the inhabitants Of the
latter were very much dissatisfied with the late
der in council relative TO the prohibition of Ameri
can vessels from entering their ports. A piraticai
TWO topsail schooner crulzng of the Windward
Islands, and had committed robberes several
vessels among which were some Americans.


Lozp life u6o1e sairs-A Montreal paper relates re-
markabe instance of stealing in high life. Two ladies OF
respectable connexions went into merchants in that
city to purchase articles. While standing at the
counter, one ut them observed by the dealer
ceal piece OF muslin under her scarf.


There were several other people in the store, and the
merchant from respect to her respectable rank and
nexons wishing expose before them ALL polite
y requested her to walk into his back shop She, suspec
ting bis object, slipped the muslin down upon the
she entered the other apartment and afterwards stouty
denied that she had the article in her hand. The attempt
theft. however, observed not only by the merchants
but by his shopman and some OF the purchasers.


The Reservoir OF the Ohio Canal, on the Licking
Summit, contracted for by Mr.. John Sheather, of
Rochester, New Yorks is completed. 1t contains
Of about 500 acres, and is intended supply
the main line the canal with in dry seasons.
The embankmeni, with wall fhewn timber n the
centre of the bank has cost the state about $500


BRISTOL, R Ion Tuesday morning last
about O'Clock, fire broke out 10 barn situated in
the south part of Bristol, owned by w. H. D'Wof,
Esq. which with its contents, and small two story
dwelling house contiguous. the property Of Mr.. Jo-
seph Waldronw ina short time entirely consumed.
In the barn at the time o,he Ere three horses,
three hogs, and several dogs, all OF which excepting
a hog and dog, were destroyed with the barn. In
attempting to rescue the animals. MIR. D'Wolf was
considerably injured.

full articles.article:
". Y. Com. .4dv.


From the ". York Com. .adrertiser, Jan. 9.


LATEST FROM ENGLAND.
BY the packet ship Corin.hian, Capt. Davis, We
have received numerous files Of London papers tc
the 25th Of November.


Letters from Palermo, Messina, and Leghorn
state that owing to the heat Of the season, most
the cargoes of fish from Newfoundland had arrived
in bad condition.
London, .top 18.
An investigation having been instituted into tn,
affairs Of the contraband packages, placed among
MIR. Secratary Canning's baggage on his return iron
France, II has been ascertained that the packages
were placed on board at Boulogne, not without tn,
concurrence of one Of the suit Of the Right Hon. Gen
tleman. Though without any address on the out
side, one of them, ON being opened, was found L
contain direction TO waiter, at the Ship Tavern
at Dover. The servant and the waiter have beer
dismissed from their respective situations.


Courier
Prince Alexander Levin, attached 10 the Russian
legation at Washington, has arrived in the CORN
THAN.


The American Minister transacted business or
the 22d with Mr.. Secretary Canning, a, his office il
Downing street.


The Answer to the Kings Speech was moved il
the Rouse OF conrnens on the 2lst, and carried b,





Humes and Brougham's opposition TO the contrar,
notwithstanding.
In the course Of the debate. Mr.. Canning declare,
that the Parliament had been summoned at this in
| convenient season, for the purpose Of sanctoniDe
the necessary assumption Of power by the ministers
in regard to the partial opening of the ports. fo
oats, beans, &c. sc.
We learn also, from Mr.. Canning's speech, tha
Ministers did not mean to shrink from the question
4af.p -
their intention to bring forward the subject immed
a,eIy after the recess. But they would be driver
to a premature discussion We also learn iron
this speech, that


Nothing but the presence Of strong British ar.
mament, in the Tagus, has saved Portugal from
invasion by the Spaniards-- Ferdinand being vastl,
displeased at the introduction OF the new Consttu
tion.


Mr.. Southey has declined the seat to which he
was elected in Parament--not possessing the re-
quisite real estate.


The malady in Groningcn had not abated.
A fire in Batavia had destroyed l80 houses.
Executions were still going on in Consantinople
The Grand Seignor has executed 5000 Of his sub
ects. The ladies are thrown into the sea in sacks
A 60 gun ship, built for the Pacha Of Egypt, had
been launched at Leghorn.


Six unsuccessful attacks had been made upon the
Acropolis by the Turks.


a Mausoeum Is 10 De erected al otratordupon
Avon to the memory Of Shakespeare. The king
subscribed 1901.


The order for prohibiting the expectation OF arms
ammunition and naval stores, is renewed.


A paper OF the 22d, says, bills for large amount
drawn by the Mexican government, were presented
yesterday, but acceptance was refused.


A cotton mill belonging TO Cussons, Bradley &
Wilde, at Oldham, has been destroyed by 6re with
machinery, &c., valued at So,o0ol., principally in
sured.


The long pending treaty between Persia and Eng.
land, has been received in London.


The pe,sians claim some successe, over the Rus
slams.


The Times renews the rumor that the exertions
Of England and France have induced the Turks to
make concessions in favor of the Greeks. There is
no good foundation for the rumor.
London, .Nov. 25.
1t is stated from Vienna and Bucharest that the
Sultan had ratified the Convention of Akerman be
fore the expiration Of the stipulated period of four
weeks.


The news from Greece is generally Of a more fa-
vorablc aspect A great number of the inhabitants
of Rumelia had rebelled against the Porte.
Major Wilcox has arrived this morning at the
East India House, over land from India. This Off
has brought the long pending treaty between this
country and Persia.
